frameDefinitions: A Manner describes general or specific characteristics of an event in one of three ways:  First, it can refer to how a Comparison_event transpires, absent the influence of an entity (e.g. 'the way you talk').
This frame has to do with the repetition (and especially the frequency of repetition) of an event.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
A Theme that is in motion assumes a new Direction in which it moves.

A Theme changes location with respect to a salient location, which can be expressed by a Source, Path, Goal, Area, Direction, Path_shape, or Distance, as shown in the examples below: ''  'Start your ascent from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.'
frameExamples: The dog went that <t>way</t>towards the ice cream factory.
He completed the task in a fervent <t>manner</t>.
China will have to face a high <t>frequency</t> of sand storms in the years to come.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
We took our chances and <t>turned</t> right by a petrol station and, bingo, there she was--Fir Park.
Start your <t>ascent</t> from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that traverses the trajectory.
The <fen>Source</fen> profiles the region where the <fen>Theme</fen> has travelled from (i.e. the region where the <fen>Theme</fen>'s movement began).

The <fen>Path</fen> is the region upon which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels. It is any region in between the <fen>Source</fen> (where the <fen>Theme</fen> departed from) and the <fen>Goal</fen> (where the theme will eventually arrive).
The <fen>Goal</fen> profiles the region at the end of the <fen>Theme</fen>'s <fen>Path</fen>. This is the region where the <fen>Theme</fen> movement stops.

The <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is the principal event being characteriszed by the <fen>Manner</fen>. The <fen>Manner</fen> of this <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is often used in comparison with the <fen>Foreground_event</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is associated with or directly responsible for the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
The description of the <fen>Comparison_event</fen> or <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
A description of the <fen>Manner</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> conducts or engages in the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen> that is being described.
This role is used for any (bounded) <fen>Event</fen> whose frequency or iteration is described.
The extent to which the actually observed rate of occurrence of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> differs from the expected rate.
The <fen>Interval</fen> is a noun modified by the target word. The target word specifies the frequency of the <fen>Interval</fen> .
The <fen>Time_span</fen> is the length of time of the <fen>Interval</fen>. This role is incorporated by most of the lexical units in this frame.
The number of times per unit of real or scanning time that an <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> is encountered.
An entity which the implicit cognizer encounters with the specified frequency.
The frequency feature of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is under discussion. All the lexical units in this frame incorporate this frame element.
The Time when the Event has a particular frequency.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.

This is the object which moves. In many sentences this role will be expressed as something which moves under its own power. However, this role is not <ment>required</ment> to be an animate mover, so it is different from a self-mover.
The new direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> continues its motion.
The time at which the change of direction takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the setting where the change of direction during the Theme's motion occurs.

This is the object which moves. In many sentences this role will be expressed as something which moves under its own power. However, this role is not <ment>required</ment> to be an animate mover, so it is different from Self_mover.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> (see below) expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>, including directional expressions:
Any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element Goal.
Any expression which characterizes the extent of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Distance</fen>.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> of the <fen>Theme</fen>, taken simultaneously.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> goes.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
listRoleExamples: The country has been struck by frequent <fex>economic crises</fex>.
The Crested Lark (Galerida cristata) is  <fex>very</fex> frequent from the coastal plain to the mountains.
The meetings occurred at fortnightly <fex>intervals</fex>.
You have to renew the license every <fex>year</fex> .
The state government spends its fiscal year 2006 budget of $23.4 billion at a rate <fex>of $742 per second</fex>.
It costs about US$2.50 to travel 200km (124 mi), but <fex>buses</fex> are infrequent and only one or two buses a day service most routes.
These exposures were likely to be intermittent <fex>in frequency</fex> occurring only when workers were participating in activities at these specific areas.
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
At that point <fex>the truck in front of me</fex> turned right into the huge ditch/field that separates the interstate from the access road.
Eventually, though, I backtracked to Kel Tole and hung a <fex>left</fex> toward Kilgal Tole.
<fex>Then</fex> I turned left onto 220th Street.
Turn right <fex>at the stop light</fex> and follow Park Avenue.
<fex>Kim</fex> crossed through the woods.
The cat crossed the street <fex>from her yard</fex>.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children hopped <fex>into the neighbor's yard</fex>.
I leaped <fex>twenty feet</fex> before slipping and falling.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
He circled downward <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The frogs jumped <fex>down</fex> through the meadow.
They crisscrossed the country <fex>in April</fex>.
